direction.raw_text: Belle, mais plus subtil plus implicite, Pablo.

direction.raw_text: You're right Gertrude - of course you can see why he's lost his objectivity. (flirting with her)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You've made a creation of Place Pigalle, a whore with volcanic appetites.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mais c'est comme elle est, si vous la connaissez.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes - avec vous en prive - because she's your lover - but we don't know her that way - so you make a petit bourgeoise judgment and turn her into an object of pleasure. (MORE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : (2) 31                                                            31 STEIN (cont'd) C'est plus comme une nature morte qu'on portrait. It's more like a still life than a portrait.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Je ne suis pas d'accord.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And what about this book of yours I've been hearing about? (to Hemingway) Have you read it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, this I leave to you. You've always been the best judge of my work.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "Out of the Past was the name of the store and its products consisted of memories. What was prosaic and even vulgar to one generation had been transmuted by the mere passing of years to a status at once magical and also camp. " ADRIANA I love it.     I'm already - hooked? Hooked.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll start it tonight. But first we have something to talk about. She collars Hemingway and they huddle to one side. Picasso has busied himself at a distant spot with a drink, sulking. This leaves Gil off with Adriana to chat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did my opening lines really get to you that strongly?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The past has always had a great charisma for me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : (3) 31                                                       31 GIL Me too.     I was born too late.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oui, exactement. For me Belle Epoque Paris would have been perfect. The whole sensibility, the street lamps, the kiosks - the horse and carriages. And Maxims - then.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You speak very good English.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, not really.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes - and how long have you been dating Picasso? My god, did I say that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pardon.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh - I - no, I didn't mean anything - you know - to pry  born in Paris?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was born in Bordeaux - I moved here to study fashion and - you don't want to hear this -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, I do.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I came here - to study with Coco Chanel - and I fell in love with Paris and also a very dark eyed, haunted, Jewish-Italian painter - and I knew Amedeo had another woman but still I couldn't resist moving into his apartment when he asked and it was a beautiful six months.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not Modigliani? Was it Modigliani? You lived with Modigliani?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : (4) 31                                                      31 ADRIANA You asked me so I'm telling you my sad story. With Braque also there was another woman - many - and now with Pablo - I mean Pablo is married but every day it's on again, off again - I don't know how any woman can stay with him - he's so difficult.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My god you are a whole different level of art groupie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pardon.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nothing - I'm -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But tell me about yourself. Have you come to Paris to write because these days so many Americans feel the need to move here. Isn't Hemingway attractive? I love his writing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Actually I'm visiting.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh you must stay here. It's a wonderful city for artists and writers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Believe me, I want to but it's not that simple.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And I did fall madly in love with the start of your book so I want to hear the rest of it. Hemingway and Stein return.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come, let's all go for a drink up at Montmartre.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : (5) 31                                                               31 STEIN We'll discuss your book as soon as I finish it. Where can I reach you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh that's okay - I'll drop by - it'll be easier for you - if that's okay.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We run an open house.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You sure you won't come?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I only wish I could but I can't - but hopefully I'll see you again -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That would be nice. Hemingway, Picasso and Adriana are going off - Hemingway flirtatious with her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: One of these days I plan to steal you away from this genius who's great but no Miro.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : EXT. HOTEL - NIGHT 32                                                                32 Gil returning. CUT TO: INT. HOTEL SUITE - NIGHT 33                                                                33 Gil gets into bed with Inez. She's asleep and he lies awake thinking. He pinches himself to make sure he's awake. 41 CONTD: 33                                                          33 GIL (to himself) I'm Gil Pender - I was with Hemingway and Picasso - Pablo Picasso - Ernest Hemingway - I'm Gil Pender from Pasadena - the Cub Scouts - I failed freshman English - I'm Gil Pender and my novel is with Gertrude Stein - I once worked at The House of Pies. I'm little Gil Pender. And that girl was so lovely. CUT TO: EXT. FLEA MARKET - DAY 34                                                             34 Gil, Inez and Helen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's a shame you two didn't come to the movies last night. We saw a wonderfully funny American film. I forget the name.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wonderful but forgettable.     I've seen that picture.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know it was moronic and infantile and lacking any wit or believability but John and I laughed in spite of ourselves.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What time did you get in?     I was dead asleep.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not late. I find these midnight strolls are very good for me creatively - without the distractions of the day - I'll probably take another long walk tonight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We'll see.     Oh how about this?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 34                                                            34 HELEN Oh look at these wonderful glass figures. As they're preoccupied, Gil is caught up by a woman who plays some old 78 records on an old phonograph and she's playing the Cole Porter tune Cole was playing the other night.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: C'est jolie, no.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes - very beautiful.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cole Porter. Vous aimez - you like Cole Porter?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Love his music - we're very close - Cole, Linda and I. She gives him a look.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Very pretty and tres amusant. He listens. Inez comes over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gil - Gil - Gil?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Huh?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We should go. We're meeting Paul and Carol for a private showing at the museum.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: With the same sharp guide?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's a different museum and we don't need a guide. Paul's an expert on Monet. (MORE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We can see all those beautiful water lilies at his home.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : INT. L'ORANGERIE MUSEUM - DAY 35                                                                      35 Paul, Carol, Inez and Gil in circular room with huge Monets.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The juxtaposition of color is amazing. This man was the real father of abstract expressionism. I take that back, maybe Turner.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I prefer Monet. I mean I love Turner but this is overwhelming.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If I'm not mistaken it took him two years to complete this. And he worked out at Giverny - where he frequently -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They say Monet used to -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shhh. I want to hear what Paul's saying.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He was frequently visited by Caillebotte - an artist I personally feel was underrated.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I find Monet almost too pretty - like Renoir - sometimes it's cloying.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : INT. ANOTHER FLOOR OF THE MUSEUM - DAY                        A36 A36 PAUL (coming to Picasso's portrait of Adriana) Ah - now here's a superb Picasso. 44 CONTD:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gil is stunned.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If I'm not mistaken he painted this marvelous portrait of his French mistress Madeline Brissou in the twenties.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Er - I have to differ with you on this one.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Really?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gil pay attention and you'll learn something.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If I'm not mistaken this was a failed attempt to capture a young French girl named Adriana - from Bordeaux - if my art history serves me - came to Paris to study costume design for the theatre. Believe she had a brief affair with Modigliani - then Braque - that's where Pablo met her - er Picasso. You'd never know it from this portrait but she's quite subtly beautiful.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What have you been smoking?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And I'd hardly call the picture superb. It's more of a petit bourgeoise statement of how Pablo er Picasso sees her, saw her - he's distracted by the fact she was a volcano in the sack.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : INT. RESTAURANT - NIGHT 36                                                              36 John, Helen and Inez finishing fancy dinner.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Too rich for me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 36                                                        36 HELEN Where did Gil run off to?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Work - he likes to walk around Paris - the way the city is all lit up at night allegedly inspires him - It's okay. Paul and I are going dancing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where's Carol?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In bed with a bad oyster. (rising) See you later. Thanks for dinner Dad. She exits.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where does Gil go every night?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You heard her. He walks and gets ideas.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Uh-huh.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You sound skeptical.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know. I see what he earns but sometimes I think he's got a part missing. And I didn't like his remark about tea party Republicans. They're decent people who want to take back the country - they're not crypto-fascist, airhead zombies. Did you hear him say that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nevertheless I hardly think your idea of having him followed is practical.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : (2) 36                                                                  36 JOHN No? I'd like to know where he goes every night.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well we know one thing - he doesn't go dancing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : INT. FITZGERALD'S PARTY - NIGHT 37                                                                  37 Gil dancing with a woman at Fitzgerald's party.    He stops finally and Adriana wanders over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello again? How nice you're here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was at Gertrude Stein's - she's almost finished with my novel. And the Fitzgeralds invited me over and said you'd be here - you and Pablo.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pablo's home - we had a bit of a quarrel. But you looked like you were having fun dancing with Djuna Barnes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That was Djuna Barnes?   No wonder she wanted to lead.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Isn't this a wonderful place to throw a party - only the Fitzgeralds would think of it. Look - this is from the turn of the century. Everything was so beautiful then. Hemingway coming over now.    He squeezes Adriana playfully flirtatious.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Isn't this little Parisienne dream a movable feast? Mark my words - I'm going to steal you from that fugitive from Malaga one way or the other. (MORE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 37                                                         37 HEMINGWAY (cont'd) (referring to his companion of the moment) Between Belmonte and myself - which of us would you choose?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Vous etes tous deux tres impressionants.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But he has more courage. He faces death more directly and more often and if you chose him I would be disappointed but understand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Por desgracia para ambos ella ha elegido Pablo.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, she's chosen Picasso - But Pablo thinks women are only to paint or sleep with.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I think women are the equal of men in courage. Have you ever shot a charging lion?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Never.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Have you ever hunted? (to Gil) Have you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Only for bargains.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to Hemingway) venga - tomemos otra copa.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to Adriana) Would you like to maybe take a walk?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 48 EXT. PLACE DAUPHINE - NIGHT 38                                                              38 Gil and Adriana walk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I hope it was nothing serious with you and Pablo?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's moody and possessive.   Artists are all like children.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I understand why they all want to paint you - you're so damn interesting to look at in a lovely way.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And you're interesting in a lost way. Tell me more about your book.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't want to talk about my book. I want to enjoy Paris by night.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I keep forgetting, you're only a tourist.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's putting it mildly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : EXT. MONTAGE/PARIS - NIGHT 39                                                              39 Adriana is showing him around.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can never decide whether Paris is more beautiful by day or by night.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's no book or painting, or symphony or sculpture that can rival a great city. All these streets and boulevards as a special art form. (MORE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 39                                                            39 GIL (cont'd) When you think in the cold, violent, meaningless universe Paris exists - these lights - I mean nothing's happening on Jupiter or Neptune or out beyond - but from way out in space you can see these lights in the whole dark void - the cafes, people drinking and dancing - I mean for all we know this town is the hottest spot in the entire universe -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Vous avez l'ame d'un poete.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're very kind. I would not call my babbling poetic.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : OMITTED 40                                                               40 EXT. PLACE PIGALLE - NIGHT 41                                                               41 Gil and Adriana are here with the street lined with prostitutes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: See anything you like?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm ashamed to admit I'm attracted to all of them. I like cheap-sexy. I know it's shallow.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: When I was in Catholic school, one weekend, my roommate and I paid one of the girls of Pigalle to come teach us all her tricks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, that's the most interesting thing I've ever heard in my life - I'd like to think about that for awhile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 50 EXT. RIVER - NIGHT 42                                                                42 Gil and Adriana walking by the river.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I love that the main character in your book sells memories.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Because he believes in his soul that progress is not automatically for the better.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Often quite the opposite.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Say - is that who I think it is?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What is she doing here? And why is she staring into the river. They see a distraught woman contemplating jumping into the river. Upon running to her, it's Zelda.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh gosh!   My god - what are you doing?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Please leave me alone.   I don't want to live.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What is it? What's going on?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It all became clear to me tonight. Scott and that beautiful Countess - it was so obvious they were whispering about me and the more they drank the more he fell in love with her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Scott loves only you. I can tell you with absolute certainty.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, he's tired of me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No you're wrong. I know.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How?   How?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Trust me.      I know.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But you just met us. How can you know anything. My skin hurts. I hate the way I look.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Take this. (pill)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What is this?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Valium - it'll calm you down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You carry medicine?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Only since Inez and I became engaged. I've had these anxiety attacks - I'm sure after the wedding they'll subside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I never heard of Valium.   What is this?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Er - it's the pill of the future.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But pills wear off - and then it all comes back. No, I won't kill myself. I'll write and I'll write more passionately than Scott. I'll work harder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He loves you. He's not with that woman. She's already on her way back to Rome.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : (2) 42                                                                 42 GIL I'll try and score some more for you. And I have some Xanax at the hotel - it's another one you'll like.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come on, we'll find a taxi. We'll see you home - things will be better in the morning.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : INT. BOHEMIAN CAFE - NIGHT 43                                                                 43 ADRIANA You never said you were getting married.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes - I - I mean it's in the future.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well good luck with your book and your wedding.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You'd like Inez - she has a sharp sense of humor - and she's sexy - not that we agree on everything.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But the important things.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Actually the small things - the important things we don't - she'd like to live in Malibu and that I'd work in Hollywood - but I will say we both like - er - er Indian food - not all Indian food - pita bread - we both like pita bread -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I should go. Pablo will be missing me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll walk you home -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 43                                                           43 ADRIANA NO, no  Finish your drink.      I live just around the corner.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, I wouldn't think -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'd prefer to be by myself for awhile. Thank you for this evening. And she goes. He's stressed, thinks. Presently Salvador Dali comes to table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We met earlier tonight.    At the party.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes - I remember -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dali - si? Dali! Dali!      Une bouteille de vin rouge I waiter scurries for one.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You like the shape of the rhinoceros?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A rhinoceros?    I never thought about it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I paint rhinoceros. I paint you - sad eyes - big lips - melting over hot sand - with one tear - yes - and in your tear - Christ's face. And rhinoceros.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sure I look sad. I'm in a very perplexing situation.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Everyone is in perplexing situation - to be or not to be - this is ultimate perplexing question - you agree? Ah - here they are -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : (2) 43                                                                 43 Bufiuel, Man Ray enter and the table enlarges as they sit. Dali introduces them to Gil.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My god, I own a surrealist print - only a print by Magritte.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pender - Pen-der - Pen-derrr - and I am Da-li. Pender is in perplexing situation.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It sounds so crazy when I say it and you'll think I'm drunk but I've got to tell someone I'm from a different time - a whole other era - the future - and I pass from the two thousandth millennium to here - a car picks me up - I slide through time -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Exactly correct - you inhabit two worlds - so far I see nothing strange.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look, you're sur-realists - but I'm a normal guy - See, in one life I'm engaged to marry a woman I love - at least I think I love her. Christ, I'm supposed to love her if I'm marrying her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Love - the word love - love - the word love - same as the word rhinoceros - the rhinoceros makes love by mounting the female - but is there difference in beauty between two rhinoceroses?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But there is nothing more sur-real than the human heart.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Past is also present.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : (3) 43                                                       43 GIL In a dream - which is fine for you because you guys dabble in dreams.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There is another woman?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Adriana is her name. And I felt drawn to her - but it wouldn't matter - men much greater than me, profound artists - she's drawn to geniuses - and they to her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I see you with Christ - he is smiling while you are crucified on the heavy wooden cross of self- doubt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of course my biggest problem is reality. BuNuEL Reality is nothing more than a dream - we all exist in the dream of a dog.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was born in the wrong time.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Time is all the mind. Time melts - the watches melt - the hands of the clock melt MAN RAY A man in love with a woman from a different era. I see a photograph. BuNuEL I see a movie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I see an insurmountable problem.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I see - a rhinoceros.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . HOTEL SUITE - DAY 44                                                                   44 Next morning.   Room service breakfast.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did you get much work done last night?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Er - some - yes - I'm beginning to think my book may be too realistic - that I've missed some chances to let my imagination run wild and not be so damn logical INEZ Shouldn't we be getting dressed?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: C'mere - you always look great in the morning.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (she does) We'll be late.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have to work. I'm working like a demon but I can't resist you half dressed like that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul says we have to see the countryside. He's taking us for lunch at this beautiful little inn. I know you like making love in the morning but I find it much sexier late afternoon - just before we go out to dinner. Except I always have to explain to my parents why your cheeks look radiant. Hey- I'm not going to force you. I know you're hot on your writing. I'll be happy when you finish this book and move on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : EXT. RODIN MUSEUM GARDEN - DAY 45                                                                   45 Gil is near The Kiss.     He has tracked down the guide. 57 CQNTD: 45
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello - Bonjour - I'd like to ask you a question about Rodin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He loved his wife, he also loved his mistress - is it really possible to be in love with two women?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He loved both in different ways.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: God it's so French. Er - you remember me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I do. Qui - you were with the group, the pedantic gentleman.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, pedantic - perfect word. You're very observant. I need some advice. I'd like a woman's take. A French woman - an observant French woman. I met some woman that I very quickly became smitten with. Smitten?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Uh-huh.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm engaged to be married. I know Rodin had a wife and a mistress but I'm American - we can't handle that - we're monogamous.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're engaged and you met a new woman -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. Her name's Adriana. Right now she's living with Picas-- with a Spaniard - er he paints - fairly well. 58 CONTD: (2) 45
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes - and does she love him?   Or you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Love him or me? Well I hardly think, me. But we've just met. See, another very gifted man flirts with her, a writer. All these geniuses fall in love with her. And what am I? And then of course there's another big problem. I can't exactly explain.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know whether to call it an age difference - or a problem of geography - I'm so messed up. I'm not Hemingway, I'm not Picasso, I'm not Rodin. I'm just a guy who was born too late.
direction.name: direction

As he goes up the stairs we learn it is the office of a private detective agency. CUT TO: INT. AGENCY OFFICE - DAY 48                                                                   48 John and M. direction.raw_text: Estoy seguro que regresara muy devoto. (English to Gil) He took her hunting kudu but she'll be back to him - the sound of hyenas every night when you're trying to sleep in a tent gets on your nerves pretty quickly. Mt. Kilimanjaro is not Paris.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They're on Mt. Kilimanjaro?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now about your book. Very unusual indeed. In a way it's almost science fiction - fiction with all the futuristic devices - television sets, supersonic flight - and yet it's not typical science fiction - it's unique. (MORE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 51                                                           51 STEIN (cont'd) Nevertheless you have to get rid of all that technology - what's good about your book are the characters - the human questions - love - mortality - nobody cares about the technology, they care about the human heart. We all fear death and question our place in the universe. Unfortunately your book lapses into easy pessimism. I was having this conversation with Giacometti the other day - he's such a gloom monger.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Still, those sculptures -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's the artist's job not to succumb to despair but to find an antidote to the emptiness of existence. I find your voice clear and lively - don't be such a defeatist.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : EXT. NOTRE DAME GARDEN - DAY 58                                                                      58 Gil with Museum Guide.    She's translating the diary into English.

direction.raw_text: That Paris exists and anyone could choose to live anywhere else in the world will always be a mystery to me. Turns pages.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dinner with Pablo and Henri Matisse. Pablo is the greater artist although Matisse is the greater painter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 58                                                   58 GUIDE (continuing) Paris in the summer - what it must have been like to sit opposite one's lover at Maxim's in it's heyday. Pages are torn and text cuts off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (continuing) I am in love with an American writer I just met named Gil Pender. His eyes widen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That immediate magic one hears about happened to me. I know that both Picasso and Hemingway are in love with me but for whatever inexplicable reasons the heart has, I am drawn to Gil. Perhaps because he seems naive and unassuming.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As always in this sad life he is about to marry a woman named Inez. I had a dream where he came to me and brought me a little gift - earrings they were - and we made love. perhaps it is just as well I accept Hemingway's offer to go to Africa. Life with Pablo is too full of conflict and I am suffocating under his genius. Why I need to go from one brilliant man to another is my weakness. Gil is different, perhaps not a genius but not moody and selfish like Pablo or Amedeo was. I think a trip to Africa with Hemingway would help get these feelings for Gil off my mind.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (finished reading) I don't understand. What is this?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : (2) 58                                                               58 GIL It's a little complicated to explain. Thanks for translating -
direction.name: direction

direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: To some women naivete is   endearing. And she's romantic. She    dreams of Belle Epoque Paris and a   gift of earrings and making love   with this man. Gil stares, thinking.
direction.name: direction

He goes to Inez's jewelry box and picks out art nouveau earrings he knows Adriana would like. He grabs a box and gift wraps it quickly. Maybe it comes in a blue velvet box and he finds some colored paper. Gil writes card: To Adriana with love. He crosses it out - To Adriana avec amour. He gives a final check to himself and opens door to leave, running smack into Inez and both her parents, home from their trip prematurely.

direction.raw_text: : INT. GERTRUDE STEIN'S PLACE - NIGHT 71                                                                        71 Gil being admitted to the Stein home.          He is full of energy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ah - Pender - I read your rewrite. Yes  you're nicely on the right track. You've understood me clearly. If the rest of the book reads as well when you're done you'll have something of value.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you. I can't tell you how much this means to me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hemingway who read your chapters and agrees it's going to be a fine book did have one plot suggestion.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hemingway read it?    What was his suggestion?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: CaNTO: 71                                                           71 STEIN He finds it hard to believe the protagonist doesn't see his fiancee is having an affair that's going on right before his eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: with -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The other character - the pedantic one -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's called denial. Thanks again. (to passing poet) You're Ezra Pound right? T.S. Eliot says you owe him forty francs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : INT. HOTEL SUITE - DAY 72                                                              72 Gil back in present in mid-argument with Inez.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're crazy - Paul and me? Where did you get such an insane notion?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: From Ernest Hemingway. He thought it out and it makes perfect sense.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gil, your brain tumor's acting up again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's nothing crazy about Ernest Hemingway or Gertrude Stein or Fitzgerald or Salvador Dali -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nothing except they've all been dead for years.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It was William Faulkner who said, the past is not dead. (MORE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In fact, it's not even past. Actually I ran into Bill Faulkner at a party.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're a raving lunatic.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I guess I'm too trusting. I'm jealous and also trusting - cognitive dissonance, Scott Fitzgerald speaks of it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gil -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know it Inez - you can fool me but not Hemingway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jesus Christ I'm dealing with a madman - okay - Paul and I had a few nights alone. We danced, we drank - you were always working - he's very attractive, he spoke to me in French - the whole mystique of this corny city got to me - it's over. We can put this all in perspective at home.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not going back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm staying here. It's not the romantic fling. Paris is Paris. It's that I'm not in love with you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A lot has happened    to me since we got here. I won't     begin to bore you - but - I know    what that feeling of love is    and it's not us.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : (2) 72                                                            72 INEZ Have you met someone else?      All those late night walks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was attracted to another woman but it was the whole deal - meeting Gertrude Stein and Hemingway and Dali and Scott and Zelda -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Honey, you better listen to yourself. You're a psycho. You don't know what you're doing. You see everything here through magical colored glasses. You're a California film writer with a house in Beverly Hills with two Mercedes'. You're not some kind of twenties expatriate novelist. Her parents enter from the adjoining suite.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's going on?       We can hear every word.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If I'm not happy I'll move back. But right now I'm going to stay.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: With who? All your crazy hallucinatory friends? Mother was right about you - there's a part missing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anyone who's protagonist makes a living selling old cap pistols and Joan Crawford cut out books.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're better off without me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Go ahead. Walk the streets - gush over the Parisian light and the rooftops.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : (3) 72                                                               72 GIL Goodbye Inez. He goes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I had a private detective follow him - I knew he was up to no good.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Daddy you didn't.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I did. He saw him get into a car at midnight each night and he followed close behind.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What happened?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know. The detective agency says the detective is missing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : INT. VERSAILLES - DAY 73                                                               73 Detective Tisserant is in a period room with two stunned period occupants. They all speak French.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A qui ai-je l'honneur?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Je me suis perdu - J'ai pas du tourner au bon endroit
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Guardes!   Guardes!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Qu'on lui coupe la tete!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : OMITTED 74                                                               74 88 EXT. PONT ALEXANDRE III - NIGHT 75                                                               75 Gil walking at night. He sees someone approaching and realizes it is the girl from the Flea Market, Gabrielle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey, I know you - the girl at the flea market.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh yes - yes - the Cole Porter one.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What are you doing here?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm returning from dinner with my girlfriends. I live near here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's your name?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gabrielle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gabrielle, - I'm Gil - I just moved to Paris this week.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh I'm sure you'll love it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can I walk along with you or can I buy you a coffee? Oh god, it's starting to rain.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's okay. I don't mind getting wet. Paris is the most beautiful in the rain.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh what a thing to say.     I couldn't agree more.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I just thought about you the other day because my boss got in a whole album of Cole Porter songs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey what are those bells?
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (waves her off and goes to get a drink)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (coming out if, realizing she's been talking to him)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's not the present for me - I'm from 2010.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I dropped in on you just the way we dropped in on the 1890's.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I wanted to escape my present just like you wanted to escape yours. To a golden age.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Surely you don't think the twenties are a golden age?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But I'm from the twenties and I'm tellin~ you the golden age is the Belle Epoque.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes but don't you see - to these guys the golden age was the Renaissance. They'd all trade the Belle Epoque to paint alongside Michelangelo or Titian. And those guys probably imagine life was better when Kubla Khan was around. I'm having an insight. A minor one but that accounts for the anxiety of my dream.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Last night I dreamed I ran out of zithromax - and then I went to the dentist and there was no novacaine - these people have no antibiotics -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And even in the twenties - no dishwashers - no 911 if your appendix bursts - no "movies on demand" ADRIANA But if we love each other what does it matter when we live?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Because if you stay here and this becomes your present, sooner or later you'll imagine another time was really the golden time. And so will I - I'm beginning to see why it can't work, Adriana. The present has a hold on you because it's your present and while there's never any progress in the most important things, you get to appreciate - what little progress is made - the internet - Pepto- Bismol. The present is always going to seem unsatisfying because life itself is unsatisfying - that's why Gauguin goes back and forth between Paris and Tahiti, searching - it's my job as a writer to try and come up with reasons why despite life being tragic and unsatisfying, it's still worth it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's the problem with writers - you're all so full of words - but I'm more emotional. I'm going to stay and live in Paris' most glorious time. You made a choice to leave Paris once and you regretted it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, that one I regretted but it was a real choice and I made the wrong one. This is a choice between accepting reality or surreal insanity.
dialogue.name: dialogue
